ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Develop a character, understand their wants and needs, in order to better portray them in scenes.

I developed a lot of insight into how to get into a character when acting. This ranged from exercises to center ourselves before we dove into the character, to being taught new ways to approach a scene, and really have the character we portray propel a scene, move it forward, and respond to the other person, rather than an inward focus on the minutiae of how to keep an act "convincing".

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: exposure to such a variety of new plays; prof's attention to and care of each actor
Weaknesses: the structure of the individual classes is fine, but the overall course structure wasn't the most conducive to learning. hopefully that improves; some of the key terminology he used wasn't the clearest so just make sure you push for more concrete definitions, or that you're able to understand what he means and redefine it for yourself.

Professor Wallace strikes a great balance with being accommodating with Zoom lectures and the length of the course - giving us breaks, giving us a wide option of choices to choose from for scenes, etc - while also pushing us to be more bold and daring with our acting choices.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Because it was over Zoom, we had to find innovative ways to make the best out of acting for each other through a screen, and Professor Wallace was very understanding about that situation.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Sure. Wallace takes more of a cerebral approach to things which I personally didnt find the most informative, but its still good to try and see what works for you and get what you can out of it. It's also good to work your acting muscle if you haven't much. Good exposure to a lot of different theatrical works, too.
Yes! Great to develop your skills as an actor.
Yes, I would definitely recommend for anyone who wants to improve their acting skills and bring nuance and richness to their characters.
